G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, which grants jurisdiction to the Superior Court for civil actions where the controversy exceeds $25,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Suffolk County pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1 because the incident giving rise to this action occurred in Boston, Massachusetts, which is located in Suffolk County.

See G.L. c. 90, \u00a7 14 (\u201cNo pers.raw_text: See G.L. c. 90, § 14 (“No person shall open a door of a motor vehicle unless it is reasonably safe to do so and can be done without interfering with the movement of other traffic.”).
See G.L. c. 90, \u00a7 14 (\u201cNo pers.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care in the operation of their vehicle and in the opening of vehicle doors adjacent to marked bike lanes.

See *Powers v. Freetown-Highway Dept.*,.raw_text: See *Powers v. Freetown-Highway Dept.*, 23 Mass. App. Ct. 700, 703 (1987) (negligence consists of failing to exercise reasonable care under the circumstances).
See *Powers v. Freetown-Highway Dept.*,.proposition: Defendant’s actions constitute negligence under well-established Massachusetts law.
See *Powers v. Freetown-Highway Dept.*,.case_name: R & F Micro Tool Co. v. General American Life Insurance
See *Powers v. Freetown-Highway Dept.*,.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns insurance contract lapse, waiver, and estoppel; it does not analyze or define negligence or the standard of reasonable care. The court resolves questions about policy lapse and reinstatement, not tort duties or breach of a duty of care, so it cannot be cited as authority that defendant’s actions constitute negligence under Massachusetts law. The cited proposition about negligence comes from a different case (*Powers v. Freetown-Highway Dept.*), not from this opinion.
See *Powers v. Freetown-Highway Dept.*,.relevant_excerpt: There is nothing suspect about a contract term that causes a policy to lapse where a premium remains unpaid at the expiration of a stated grace period. Such policy provisions have been duly enforced. See Shurdut v. John Hancock Mut. Life Ins. Co., 320 Mass. 728, 730 (1947).... The employer grants that there was a lapse on July 31, 1982, but it contends that by “waiver” on the part of the insurer, or an “estoppel” against the insurer, the policy should be considered reinstated...

See *Beaudette v. Department of Conserva.raw_text: See *Beaudette v. Department of Conservation & Recreation*, 94 Mass. App. Ct. 374, 377 (2018) (an operator is negligent where they fail to keep a proper lookout).
See *Beaudette v. Department of Conserva.proposition: Defendant’s act of looking at their phone rather than checking for bicyclists or other traffic demonstrates additional negligence.
